G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the incident occurred within Hampden County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because Defendant resides in this county and the cause of action arose here.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a duty of reasonable care is imposed upon all persons to act to prevent foreseeable injury to others arising from their conduct.

Jescrome Realty Co. v. Northeast Airline.raw_text: Jescrome Realty Co. v. Northeast Airlines, Inc., 195 N.E.2d 379 (Mass. 1964)
Jescrome Realty Co. v. Northeast Airline.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a duty of reasonable care is imposed upon all persons to act to prevent foreseeable injury to others arising from their conduct.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to act as a reasonable person would under the circumstances—to secure his personal property (the ladder) so as not to pose an unreasonable risk of harm to persons or property lawfully using the shared driveway.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurrence discussing the abolition of the invitee/licensee distinction and critiquing continued reliance on the trespasser category. It does not address, much less establish, a specific duty to secure a ladder or other personal property in a shared driveway, nor does it articulate the concrete standard of care described in the proposition. Therefore, this citation does not support the claimed duty about securing personal property in the manner asserted.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by permitting an unsecured aluminum extension ladder to remain propped against a fence adjacent to a shared driveway, despite knowing and being warned of the hazard it presented.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a restaurant had a duty to protect patrons from an out‑of‑control vehicle striking the building; it does not involve an unsecured ladder, a shared driveway, or warnings about a hazard. The court’s holding is that the particular incident was not reasonably foreseeable and thus no duty was breached, which is the opposite of asserting that a defendant breached a duty in the ladder scenario described. Therefore, it does not support the specific negligence proposition claimed.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.relevant_excerpt: “Based on the evidence presented, there could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred. … The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

Crone v. Jordan Marsh Co., 269 Mass. 289.raw_text: Crone v. Jordan Marsh Co., 269 Mass. 289 (1929)
Crone v. Jordan Marsh Co., 269 Mass. 289.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions were unreasonable under the circumstances and demonstrated disregard for foreseeable harm.
Crone v. Jordan Marsh Co., 269 Mass. 289.support_reasoning: The case holds that the defendant did not breach its duty of reasonable care under the circumstances because the danger (a small rug on a highly polished floor) was obvious and known to the plaintiff, and thus there was no actionable negligence. The opinion explicitly concludes that the evidence did not warrant a finding that the defendant failed to use reasonable care, which is contrary to the proposition that the defendant’s acts and omissions were unreasonable and demonstrated disregard for foreseeable harm.
Crone v. Jordan Marsh Co., 269 Mass. 289.relevant_excerpt: “If it was found, as the evidence fully warranted, that the plaintiff was in the store by the invitation of the defendant as a customer, the defendant owed to her the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in safe condition for her use as a customer… The evidence did not warrant the finding that the defendant failed to perform this duty. The case is not distinguishable from Kitchen v. Women’s City Club of Boston… where it was held that [plaintiff]… by assenting, negatived the existence of any duty on the part of the defendant to warn her of such dangers.”

Leavitt v. Mizner, 404 Mass. 81 (1989).proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were foreseeable because unsecured objects, such as ladders, are likely to fall and cause damage when exposed to strong winds.
Leavitt v. Mizner, 404 Mass. 81 (1989).support_reasoning: The opinion is a legal malpractice/summary judgment decision focused on causation and the standard for newly discovered evidence. It does not discuss tort foreseeability, wind, unsecured objects, ladders, or any analogous facts about falling objects causing damage. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that damages were foreseeable because unsecured objects like ladders are likely to fall in strong winds.
Leavitt v. Mizner, 404 Mass. 81 (1989).relevant_excerpt: Rule 56 (c) of the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, 365 Mass. 824 (1974), provides that summary judgment is appropriate “if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.” “The party moving for summary judgment assumes the burden of affirmatively demonstrating that there is no genuine issue of material fact on every relevant issue, even if he would have no burden on an issue if the case were to go to trial.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence within the meaning of Massachusetts law.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence; it affirms summary judgment for the defendant because plaintiffs failed to produce evidence of causation and possibly duty. The opinion explains the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law and applies them to conclude that plaintiffs could not show the defendant’s conduct caused their injuries. Thus, the case is authority for the insufficiency of the plaintiffs’ negligence showing, not for the proposition that the defendant’s conduct was negligent.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The record reflects that the plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them…. No rational jury could find in the plaintiffs’ favor on that issue based on the proffered evidence.”

Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2.raw_text: Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2 Mass. App. Ct. 577 (1974)
Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover for the full measure of property damage and associated expenses caused by Defendant’s negligent act or omission, consistent with Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2 Mass. App. Ct. 577 (1974), and McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 398 Mass. 152 (1986).
Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth. reproduced here is actually a criminal case about improper impeachment of a defendant through comment on his pretrial silence and related jury instructions. It does not involve property damage, negligence, or the measure of recoverable damages and associated expenses. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to recover the full measure of property damage and related costs caused by a defendant’s negligence.
Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2.relevant_excerpt:
The judgment of conviction for assault with intent to murder is reversed and the jury’s verdict on that indictment is set aside. The judgment of conviction for assault and battery with a dangerous weapon is affirmed.

…

In effect, the Commonwealth sought to require the defendant to assert his innocence immediately or not at all. Such methods cannot be approved, for they contravene the provisions of the Federal and Massachusetts constitutions and the public policy of this Commonwealth as declared in its statutes.

McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co..raw_text: McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 398 Mass. 152 (1986)
McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover for the full measure of property damage and associated expenses caused by Defendant’s negligent act or omission, consistent with Katon v. Massachusetts Turnpike Auth., 2 Mass. App. Ct. 577 (1974), and McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 398 Mass. 152 (1986).

Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 1.proposition: Plaintiff did not suffer personal physical injury or medical expenses; however, her property damage and related economic losses are compensable.
Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a personal injury/products liability case where the plaintiff suffered a crushed hand; the court’s discussion assumes and affirms recovery for personal physical injury, not just property or economic loss. Nowhere does the court address a situation where there is no personal physical injury or medical expense, nor does it separately analyze compensability of purely property or economic damages. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition that a plaintiff without physical injury or medical expenses may nevertheless recover for property damage and related economic losses.
Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co., 407 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that ‘the defendant breached its warranty of merchantability in that it failed to warn of dangerous conditions. The machine in its condition was not of merchantable quality. As a result, [the] plaintiff’s hand became caught and crushed by the machine . . . .’ … The defendant further objects to the application of G. L. c. 93A to products liability cases involving personal injury. … We see no reason to exclude injury to the person from the category of injuries cognizable under G. L. c. 93A.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award costs, interest, and reasonable attorney’s fees as authorized by law under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
